Statement: A meteoroid hit the outer pane. The crack is small but terrifying.
Another holiday spent in orbit. It never gets easier.
Another sleepless night. The glare from the moon is too bright through the port.
Ate lunch while looking at the Andes. Not a bad office view.
Battery arrays are charging at 105% efficiency today.
Capcom, thanks for the music uplink. It really boosted morale in the hab.
Celebrating a crew birthday with freeze-dried cake. We made the best of it.
CO2 scrubbers are saturating faster than expected. I’m feeling lightheaded.
Communication lag is making this procedure nearly impossible.
Coolant leak in the main rack. Everything is getting soaked.
Docking confirmed. The latching mechanism engaged perfectly on the first try.
Every time I look out the window, I feel a deep sense of dread.
Everything feels weightless and effortless today. I love this environment.
Finally finished my two-hour workout. Feeling strong.
Got a surprise call from my wife on the comms. My heart is finally full.
Ground control sent up photos from home. I can't stop smiling.
Ground control, the habitat pressure is fluctuating. It's making it hard to sleep.
Hydraulic pressure is fluctuating wildly in the landing gear.
I can see my home state passing below. It's beautiful and painful at once.
I can see the plasma fire outside the window. It's terrifyingly beautiful.
I can't get the smell of burnt metal out of the airlock.
I can't stop thinking about the distance between me and my family right now.
I can't wait to feel the wind on my face again.
I dropped the torque wrench and watched it drift into the dark. I feel so stupid.
I feel a deep sense of purpose, but the cost of being here is high.
I feel like a ghost haunting a high-tech machine. The isolation is deep.
I feel like a ghost watching the world go by without me.
I feel like a lab rat in a very expensive cage.
I feel like a spectator in my own life. Everything is so clinical.
I feel like I'm losing the ability to talk about anything but the mission.
I feel like I'm forgetting what a breeze feels like on my face.
I feel like I'm losing my sense of time. One day bleeds into the next.
I feel so disconnected. The delay in the video calls makes it worse.
I feel so small in the face of this infinite darkness.
I finally finished the repairs. My hands are sore but I feel proud.
I had a nightmare about the airlock opening. I'm on edge.
I have a pounding headache from the CO2 buildup in the sleep station.
I haven't felt the sun on my skin in 200 days. It's depressing.
I just want to walk on grass. Just for five minutes.
I keep checking the calendar. Three months is still a very long time.
I managed to do a backflip today without hitting anything!
I missed my daughter's birthday today. It's hard to be this far away.
I think I have a stress fracture in my foot. Walking is painful.
I'd give anything for a home-cooked meal that doesn't come out of a pouch.
I'm counting the orbits until I can finally go home.
I'm dreaming of rain every single night now.
I'm finding it harder to focus on the checklists today. Brain fog.
I'm staring at the Pacific and imagining I'm sitting on the beach.
I'm struggling to remember what the air feels like when it's not recycled.
I'm tired of being a pioneer. I just want to sit in a park.
I'm worried about the structural integrity of the airlock seal.
I'm worried I won't remember how to walk once I get back.
I'm covered in bruises from bumping into the bulkheads.
I'm seeing strange flashes in my eyes—the cosmic rays are hitting hard.
I'm tired of being told what to do by people who aren't up here.
I'm worried I'm becoming a stranger to my own children.
It's hard to care about the mission when I'm worried about things back home.
Just saw a meteorite impact the surface a few miles away. Terrifyingly beautiful.
Looking at the Earth makes me feel profoundly connected to everyone.
Looking at the Earth through the dust of the lunar surface is humbling.
Looking at the moon makes me feel like a pioneer on the edge of forever.
Managed to catch a solar flare on the spectrometer. Pure scientific gold.
Managed to fix the plumbing! Small victories are the best victories.
Managed to get a clear signal for the family call. Best day in weeks.
Missing the simple feeling of gravity—of just sitting in a chair.
Missing the smell of rain and the sound of wind in the trees.
My daughter drew me a picture and held it up to the camera. I’m a mess.
My hands are shaking from the adrenaline after that close approach.
My joints ache and the lack of gravity is making my head feel heavy.
My muscles are cramping from the lack of traditional movement.
My skin is so dry and itchy in this artificial atmosphere.
My vision is getting blurry; the fluid shift is hitting me hard.
One of the crew members is showing signs of severe cabin fever.
Our mission patch looks great on the bulkhead. Proud to be here.
Oxygen pressure is dropping. We are moving to the Soyuz for safety.
Power levels are green across all four quadrants. Looking good.
Seeing my home country from up here makes me feel so patriotic.
Seeing the aurora from above is like watching a neon ghost.
Seeing the blue marble makes me realize how lucky we are to have a home.
Shared a joke with MCC. It's nice to know there are people on the other side.
Sharing a meal with the team is the highlight of my day.
Sleeping in zero-G feels like floating on a cloud.
Static on the comms is making it impossible to hear ground control instructions.
Successful deployment of the microsats! Watching them drift away was serene.
Successful landing! We are officially the first humans in this sector.
Successfully initiated the first Mars-Earth high-gain link. Crystal clear.
Successfully synced the internal clocks with UTC. Minor but satisfying.
The air is getting thin in the sleeping quarters. I'm waking up gasping.
The air smells like wet dog today. The filters are definitely shot.
The airlock sensors are giving a false positive for a vacuum leak.
The airlock won't cycle. We're trapped in the module for now.
The atmosphere tonight is calm. Just me, the stars, and the hum of life.
The aurora borealis from this altitude looks like a neon river.
The autonomous rover is stuck in a sand trap. Attempting a remote override.
The backup generator kicked in just in time. That was close.
The backup oxygen tank is pressurized. We have a safety net now.
The biolab is flourishing; the lettuce is actually growing quite tall!
The bone density scan results are disappointing; the exercise isn't enough.
The camaraderie during the emergency drill was impressive. I trust these people.
The camaraderie up here is the only thing keeping me sane.
The capsule is shaking violently. I hope the tiles hold up.
The centrifuge is making a screeching sound. Science is on hold.
The coffee machine is fixed! This is the best day of the mission.
The commander gave me a pat on the shoulder today. I really needed that.
The communications delay is now 20 minutes. The silence is heavy.
The computer keeps rebooting for no reason. I’m losing my mind.
The computer keeps throwing a 'General System Failure very helpful, Houston.
The constant hum of the ventilation fans is starting to drive me crazy.
The crew had a movie night. It felt almost like being home.
The crew is bickering over the smallest things. We’re all just tired.
The crew is my family now. We've seen each other at our absolute worst.
The crystal growth experiment is showing structures we've never seen on Earth.
The cupola provides the best seat in the universe. I could stay here forever.
The data downlink is lightning fast today. Excellent work by the ground.
The data downlink just hit a new record speed. Great job, ground!
The data we collected today will change textbooks forever.
The docking latches are jammed with grit. We're stuck for now.
The docking port is misaligned. This could be a disaster if we don't fix it.
The drone's rotors are damaged. We've lost our aerial scout.
The dust storm is blocking the solar panels. Power is critical.
The Earth looks so fragile from here; we really must take care of it.
The Earth looks so peaceful, but it feels a million miles away today.
The emergency siren is the worst sound I've ever heard in my life.
The EVA went smoothly; there is nothing like floating in the abyss.
The experimental plasma engine fired for the full duration. Milestone reached!
The first breath of fresh air from the resupply pod was heavenly.
The first sunset on Mars... the sky is blue, not red. It's beautiful.
The food paste is bland. I would kill for something with a crunch.
The fuel cells are behaving erratically under high load.
The geological samples are rich in silicates. This is exactly what we wanted.
The greenhouse is blooming! We have actual flowers in space.
The ground team's quick thinking saved our science payload. Great job.
The heat shield inspection came back clean. Huge weight off my mind.
The hydraulic fluid has a leak; the robotic arm is limp.
The insulation is peeling off the exterior. The heat is seeping in.
The isolation is a physical weight today. I feel trapped in this metal box.
The landing struts didn't deploy evenly. We're tilted at five degrees.
The landing was rough. I think I bit my tongue.
The landing was smooth as silk. We are home.
The lunar dust is everywhere; it's clogging the joint seals in my suit.
The main battery won't hold a charge above sixty percent.
The med-bay is fully stocked, but I hope we never have to use it.
The medical officer says my vitals are perfect. Great news.
The med-kit is missing the specific antibiotics I need for this infection.
The mission duration was extended. I don't know if I can do another month.
The mission is complete. Every objective met. I'm coming home.
The new drill bit is cutting through the lunar regolith like butter.
The night pass over Europe was stunning. The lights look like gold dust.
The noise levels in the Zvezda module are dangerously high today.
The noise of the station is constant; it's a mechanical headache.
The 'Overview Effect' is real. I feel a profound love for every soul down there.
The oxygen generator is making a grinding noise. I don't like it.
The parachute deployed! We are floating down to the ocean.
The perspective from here makes human conflicts seem so small.
The plant experiment died overnight. I feel like I failed them.
The primary cooling loop has flatlined; we are in a serious heat excursion.
The propellant levels are optimal for the return burn. We're coming home!
The protein crystals are forming perfectly. This is a breakthrough.
The radiation alarm woke us up, but it was just a solar flare glitch. Relief.
The radiation levels are climbing due to the solar storm. We're hunkering down.
The radiation shielding has a breach; we need to move to the core.
The recovery ship is in sight. We made it back.
The recycled air tastes metallic today. It's making me nauseous.
The re-entry calculations are slightly off. I'm terrified.
The robotic arm is stuck in an extended position. Total gridlock.
The robotic arm is unresponsive. We are stuck until we get a reboot.
The sample return canister is sealed and ready for the trip back.
The seals are hissing. I think we have a slow pressure leak.
The sense of purpose I feel right now is unlike anything else.
The silence in the hab is heavy today. Everyone is missing someone.
The silence is too much tonight. I need to hear a human voice.
The silence of the Martian night is more peaceful than I expected.
The silence of the vacuum is deafening when you're out there on the hull.
The smell of ozone after the EVA is really bothering my nose.
The smell of the station is a mix of ozone and old sweat. I hate it.
The software patch worked! Systems are back to nominal.
The solar flare passed without damaging the avionics. Thank god.
The solar panels are glinting in the light. They look like gold wings.
The space sickness is back. I can't keep any food down.
The star tracker is locked on. Navigation is back to 100% accuracy.
The stars are beautiful, but they are so, so cold.
The stars don't twinkle here; they are just cold, piercing points of light.
The stretch after waking up in microgravity is pure bliss.
The suit is chafing my neck; every movement is painful during the EVA.
The suit's cooling vest failed. I'm overheating and need to get inside.
The sunrise over the Pacific is an incredible gradient of blues and oranges.
The sunset over the Indian Ocean was a perfect purple. A gift from the universe.
The support from the ground team makes me feel invincible.
The support from the ground team makes me feel less alone in the dark.
The taste of fresh water from the new filter is amazing.
The team spirit is high today; we finally finished the habitat assembly.
The team worked perfectly together to resolve the power shunting issue.
The telemetry data is drifting; I don't trust the navigation computer.
The thruster firing was crisp. We are exactly where we need to be.
The treadmill broke again. I need the endorphins or I'm going to snap.
The ventilation breeze feels good against my face.
The video link cut out while I was talking to my parents. I feel crushed.
The view from the cupola is the only thing that keeps me grounded.
The view of the Himalayas from 250 miles up is simply spiritual.
The water tastes like chemicals today. I think the ion exchange is failing.
The zero-G exercise routine is actually keeping my back pain away.
There is a strange rattling in the bulkhead that I can't identify.
There's a short in the lighting circuit; we're working in the dark.
Walking on the moon feels like a slow-motion dream. Truly surreal.
Watching the centrifuge spin is oddly hypnotic and calming.
Watching the video of my son's first steps wish I was there to hold him.
Water reclamation is down. We are dipping into the emergency reserves.
We are drifting into the shadow. The transition to night is always magical.
We are seeing a massive storm system over the Atlantic. It's awe-inspiring.
We captured a high-res image of a supernova. I'm speechless.
We fixed the comms array with a simple reboot. Sometimes the old ways work.
We found a way to recycle the waste into 3D printer filament. Ingenious.
We had a crew dinner tonight; it's the closest thing to family I have up here.
We harvested our first batch of space-grown radishes tonight. Tasted like home.
We have achieved a stable orbit. The trajectory was perfect.
We have visual contact with the rescue craft. Tears in everyone's eyes.
We have visual on the resupply craft. It's a beautiful sight.
We just broke the record for the longest human spaceflight.
We just felt the first hint of gravity. It's heavy, but we're safe.
We just found a pocket of frozen water in the shadow of the crater!
We laughed until we cried today over a floating blob of juice.
We reached the summit of the ridge. The view is unlike anything in history.
We shared a special meal tonight to celebrate the halfway mark. Good vibes.
We successfully captured the satellite! A huge win for the mission.
We watched a movie about Earth tonight. Everyone was quiet afterward.
We've been in the dark for forty minutes. The battery life is critical.
We've lost the starboard sensor array; we're flying blind on that side.
Welcome home, crew. Those words are the best thing I've ever heard.
We're running low on CO2 scrubbers. We need the resupply to arrive on time.
We're seeing a 'low oxygen' warning but the sensors seem faulty.
We've been on this mission for 400 days. The walls are closing in.
